text: Welcome to How To Cook That, I'm Ann Reardon
and this week we are making these
super cute adorable little creatures out of chocolate.
These two use moulds to make them
but this last one is super easy
and it's just made out of Easter eggs that you can buy or you might get for Easter this year
Let's start with how to make the duck.
The first thing you need to do
is add some orange oil based food coloring to some tempered white chocolate
or if you don't wanna temper it you could use compound chocolate 'cause that would be much easier.
place some of that in a mini Easter egg mould
and then bang the mould on the bench
to make sure there are no air bubbles underneath.
And then smooth off the tops
and leave that to set.
Now we will need a medium egg for the body,
a sphere for the head and a smaller egg for the wings.
Fill those with white chocolate that has been coloured yellow,
again using oil based food colouring
you can't use gel or liquid colouring or it'll just seize your chocolate.
Then flip that over and allow the excess to drip out so that you end up with a hollow egg
Clean it up around the top of each one
and then we wanna put those upside down to set
so that the top edges don't get too thin.
Repeat that with the eggs for the wings
and the sphere for the head
Now I'm using an ice cube sphere mould here for this
that's not ideal for chocolate but I reckon it'll do for today
Once they are set you can tip them out of the mould
and if the chocolate is properly tempered they should just easily flip right out of your mould
Dip one half of your sphere in chocolate
and then add it to the other half
And then do that same thing with the bigger sized egg
joining the two halves of the egg together
Now once this is set you can smooth off those joins
just using a knife to scrape off anything that's sticking out
Now to make our duck's body stand up
and not just roll off the table
we need to make a hole in the base
And to do that just take a piping tip and warm it up in some boiling water
then dry it and slowly press it into the base
and be patient as you do this it'll take a little while
And these chocolate creatures are inspired by the amazing Raul Bernal
I'll put a link to his work below
He obviously uses professional moulds
He is a professional pastry chef
But I wanted to see if we can recreate them and pull  them off
just using cheap plastic moulds
Once that goes through you've got a hole
and your egg will now sit still for you
Take your wing
and add some melted chocolate around the inside edge
and then put them into place on either side of the ducks body
Now take the head and make a hole in the base
just in the same way as we did before
so that we can attach that to the body
Just use a little bit of melted chocolate around the join
And place it on to towards the front
Take two of your mini eggs
and then using more chocolate
join them together to make the beak
For the ducks eyes I'm gonna use two chocolate truffles
one slightly bigger than the other to give it that cartoony look
And the mini orange Easter egg is for the beak
Cut a hole for the beak
And then warm up the piping tip again in the hot water
And put it into the hole just to melt a tiny bit around the edge
Now you can put that beak into place there
and once it's set it will hold it there
Do the same with the eyeballs just warming up around the edge of the hole
and then add them into place
I have over 30 recipes for chocolate truffles on the howtocookthat.net website
And I'll link you to that below
you can just choose your favourite one and make those for the eyes
Add a mini m&m for the pupil
And there you have it, cute rubber duckie!
I mean cute chocolate duckie! Haha.
I think that you're gorgeous you would make a beautiful Easter gift!
The second one we''re gonna make is the penguin
Now for this adorable little penguin we're gonna use
two orange mini half eggs
that we made while we were making the duck
And then you just need to spread some orange chocolate flat on some baking paper
shake the paper to smooth the surface out
and then place those mini half eggs on top
just a little bit apart from each other
and then leave that until it's just starting to set
but the chocolate is still soft
and cut out a penguin shaped foot
and take your knife
No right or wrong there just try to do it roughly
There we go.
Once it's set just lift off the outside piece
Make some mini yellow eggs
And you'll only actually need one half for this beak here
For the rest of the penguin you'll need
a couple of mini egg halves in black
half a black sphere for his  head
and a half a black of a larger sphere for his body
Pour the black into the mould
and I know we only need one of the heads but I like to make extra just in case it breaks.
Tip it up just like before to get the excess out
And then scrape around the top
and once they're set you can just remove them from the moulds
Now we need one more thing for our penguin
We need half a sphere in white for his tummy
So to summarize that you should have a large sphere, two mini eggs
a smaller half sphere for his head
two feet, a beak and your eyes
So putting that together use some black chocolate to add the two mini eggs to the body
Sticking out slightly like little flippers
Then take the head
and add some melted chocolate around the base
and pop it in the place between the flipppers
right towards the edge of the black
Now cut a hole in the white half of the body
right close to the edge
And this is so that the penguin will stand up and not roll over
Add some chocolate around the top edge of the white one
and then join those two halves together
Use a warm piping tip
and cut out a small amount of the inner edge of one of the feet
so that it'll tuck in close to his body
glue that into place using some white chocolate
And then add the other foot sticking out a bit like he's about to take a step
Now use a piping tip to cut half a circle out of the edge of the head
right on the edge there.
and then add the beak into place
Now you wanna cut holes for the eyes
and melt around the edge like we did  before and then add the truffles.
Then add the pupils to bring him to life.
He is so cute I don't want anyone to eat him!
Next let me show you how to make a dragon
if you are blessed enough to  get lots of Easter eggs on Easter Sunday
then you can use them to make your own creature.
To start with cut a hole in the base of a bigger egg
so that it will stand up
Then cut another hole on one side of a medium egg towards the fatter end
and then add that to the top of the body for his head.
Using a sharp knife cut around the join of the smaller eggs
slow and steady just going all the way around until it falls open into halves
Then add them to the lower part of the body for the dragons thighs.
Cut a mini egg in half and then cut a piece of each one
And add it onto the legs so it's like his little feet
Cut some more in half and add them over the head and down the back
Then take a circle cutter and remove a circle from the base
And add a small egg for the base of his tail
Now take your next egg and cut a circle from one end
add some melted chocolate around it
and add it onto the tail
and you could make his tail as long as you like.
I'm just gonna cut a small hole in the end here and put a mini egg on there
and then add a couple more halves to make it match up
Now cut two holes for his eyes
and put them into place making sure they fit but don't fix them in yet
and then add two half eggs for his little front arms
Now fix a quarter of an egg in place for his little dragon wings
Add your mini m&m's in for pupils
Then take out those eyes and take him outside
And spray your dragon with coloured cocoa butter
It can be any colour you like I'm going with red
Now you don't have to spray him you can just leave him brown of course
Add the eyes back into place
and you've just made the cutest little dragon
Now I just made him up as I went along so you can have fun creating your own chocolate creatures with your Easter eggs, too
Post a picture on the comment section on the blog
I'd love to see what you guys make
Click here for more Easter egg ideas
Here for videos about the real meaning of Easter
and here for the latest video
Make it a great week and I'll see you on Friday!
